If the audio had been resampled, you could expect less bytes, or different =
bytes, but not the same number of the same bytes.=A0 That's why comparing t=
he bytes in both files can rule that out, if no changes are found.

Yeah-I know about the file size comparison. 
Obviousl=
y if the file size became smaller, we know for sure there has been loss, 
e=
xcept if the file had been saved=A0to a lossless compression type,=A0such 
=
as=A0from RAW to TIFF in photo files.
=A0
I just don't fully trust the bit =
comparison 
because I don't trust that the bytes haven't been resampled usi=
ng interpolation, 
such as we discussed earlier. But that is largely becaus=
e I have no clue at that 
level of things what is actually going on.
=A0
Al=
l I know about this I know from Graphic 
Design experience and working with=
 photo files, so I only have 
that=A0knowledge to use to compare. I no noth=
ing about actual programming 
language, Unix, or stuff like that.
=A0
April=

=A0

e uploading 
  rules-ATTENTION JON
  

  
  
  
    
    
      They are no=
t necessarily the same bytes, but I was 
        proposing a quick check ju=
st to see if the files were in the same 
        ballpark.=A0 Look at it th=
e other way: if the number of bytes were 
        DIFFERENT, than you'd kno=
w the files HAD changed, and you could stop 
        testing.=A0 But if the=
 number of bytes are the same, it tends to 
        indicate the files are =
likely the same, but you still need a low level 
        file comparison to=
 be sure.

My method is to compare the files 
        using the CMP command=
 in unix.=A0 There are many programs to compare 
        files, but you hav=
e to be careful not to use one that does a 
        line-by-line compare (o=
r a comparison meant for text files), since text 
        files can be diff=
erent at a low level, but look essential the same in an 
        editor (be=
cause of the way spaces and tabs and new lines work between 
        editor=
s and platforms).

But anyway, the way to compare is with a 
        progra=
m that can compare binary files, not text files.

 =
         So if the number of bytes match 
          then they are the same =
bytes? See where my confusion comes 
          in?
          =A0
          =
How does one do a bit-level 
          comparison? Is there a program that =
does that, or is there some way of 
          comparison by looking at the =
file's properties?
          =A0
          
            ----- 
            =
Original Message ----- 
            From: 
            Rj 
            To: =

            EVP-ITC@yahoogroups

    =

            Subject:

[EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON
            

            
   =
         
            
              
              
                A file=
's content, it's integrity, is simply the 
                  bytes (and the=
ir bits) in the file.=A0 If the file's 
                  content integrity=
 is changed, that is, by definition, changing 
                  the bytes.=
=A0 If the bytes in there are not changed, then 
                  that int=
egrity has not changed.

It is possible to mess 
                  with oth=
er things about a file (like its name, its suffix, or 
                  it=
s ownership) but this does not effect the contents, and so 
               =
   would not affect that integrity, or the sound of the file 
             =
     (assuming you could read it at all after changing the 
               =
   ownership, or the suffix, etc).

When you do your tests, 
              =
    if you cannot do a bit level comparison, I would recommend at 
        =
          least checking the file sizes.=A0 If they are identical, 
       =
           there is a very high probability that the content has not 
     =
             changed.

             =
         
                        
                        
               =
           Yes you can tell loss of quality by a 
                         =
   bit-level comparison.=A0 An audio file is just a 
                      =
      file of bytes, that is later interpreted by an audio 
               =
             player.=A0 Two files with the exact same 
                    =
        contents, whether they are audio or image or a 
                   =
         dababase or an exe, are indistinguishable from each 
             =
               other.=A0 That is, if I copied the contents of 
            =
                one to a new file, and the contents of the other to 
      =
                      a new file, and asked you which file each came from, =

                            there would be no way to tell.=A0 Even the aud=
io 
                            player could not tell.=A0 The data is ident=
ical, 
                            and so the sound (or the picture, etc) w=
ould be 
                            identical.

Yes I did listen to the re=
sults, 
                            but that is not the best test (they sou=
nded 
                            identical, but that is a subjective opini=
on).=A0 
                            The real test is compring the contents=
.=A0 
                            Identical contents means indentical data,=
 means 
                            identical audio.

It is probably possib=
le to 
                            set up an email compression scheme that =
does do 
                            lossy audio compression.=A0 My tests s=
how my 
                            setup does not.=A0 If you'd like me to =
help test 
                            your setup, we can do that too. From=
 what I see, 
                            lossy compression from an attachm=
ent would be very 
                            unusual.

nd sent

iginal, and the ones sent around

 They were all identical, which

                        =
        
                                
                                
=
                                For 
                                execut=
ables, you may be right. However, for wav 
                                =
files, the compression during email is not loss 
                          =
      less. 
                                =A0
                          =
      I used to 
                                think as you do, in that t=
he emailed 
                                attachment=A0of a wav file woul=
d not loose 
                                anything. After a lengthy disc=
ourse with another 
                                member here, I learned =
that I was wrong. The 
                                reason why=A0I did n=
ot realize it in the 
                                first place is that w=
hen I would email a wav 
                                file, I would inte=
ntionally keep it in very 
                                small segments, =
to keep file size down. This was 
                                just for =
ease of transfer. But because of this, 
                                I h=
ad not experienced any noticeable 
                                loss.
  =
                              =A0
                                Now it ma=
y 
                                be in some cases, depending on the serve=
rs or 
                                what have you that the file goes thr=
ough, that 
                                the loss may be less or more. B=
ut once the 
                                attachment is 
               =
                 downloaded,=A0the=A0quality=A0has been 
                  =
              found to be less then the original 
                         =
       wav.
                                =A0
                           =
     Again though 
                                you can only really tell=
 when the=A0wav file 
                                is large.
           =
                     =A0
                                ----- Original Mes=
sage ----- 
                                
                              =
  From: 
                                Rj 
                              =
  
                                To: 
                                EVP=
-ITC@yahoogroups .com

                   Sunday, May 10, 2009 1:36 PM
                           =
     Subject: 
                                Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading=
 rules
                                

                                
 =
                               
                                
          =
                      
                                
                   =
             The kind of compression that 
                                =
occurs during an email attachment is "lossless": 
                         =
       it compress the file cleverly without losing 
                      =
          information.=A0 For example, if I had a 
                        =
        program in some .exe files, and I sent it over 
                   =
             email, it could compress it.=A0 But if it 
                   =
             lost even one bit, the resulting exe file would 
             =
                   not execute again after it was uncompressed on 
        =
                        the other side.

This kind of compression 
        =
                        does things like looking for common patterns in 
  =
                              the file, and replacing them with a token.=A0=
 
                                A rough example would be if it found "How=
dy 
                                Neighbor" in a file 20 times, it could =
replace 
                                all the occurances with say $HN1.=
=A0 And also 
                                write a little dictionary in =
there someplace 
                                that says "$HN1=3DHowdy Ne=
ighbor".

When the 
                                file gets to its destin=
ation it can be 
                                uncompressed, and all occu=
rences of $HN1 are 
                                replaced with "Howdy Ne=
ighbor".=A0 So it was 
                                compressed (instead =
of 14 characters each, it 
                                only needed 4, p=
lus the dictionary), but lost no 
                                data.

So=
me formats, like jpeg and mp3. 
                                are not los=
sless.=A0 Depending on the level 
                                of compre=
ssion, some level of data is lost, and 
                                so =
cannot be recovered or reconstructed 
                                later=
.

Rick

                               =
 
                                
                                
       =
                         Another 
                                thing:
  =
                              =A0
                                I recentl=
y 
                                found this out. When you email a file, i=
f it is 
                                not saved as a compressed format, =
the email 
                                filtering process will actually =
compress the 
                                file automatically.
         =
                       =A0
                                So even if 
    =
                            you have attached a wav. file, it will loose 
 =
                               resolution over the email process. It will n=
ot 
                                sound exactly the same as the original =
wav. 
                                file. How much it differs depends on =
the size of 
                                the file you are attaching. If=
 it is a 
                                very=A0large file, it will sound =
much 
                                different.
                          =
      =A0
                                The only 
                       =
         exception to this is if the wav. file is small 
                  =
              enough that the filtering process will ignore 
              =
                  it. It has to be pretty small though, like under 
       =
                         1=A0MB (I am not exactly sure of the 
            =
                    threshold).
                                =A0
       =
                         The best way 
                                to s=
hare files over the internet=A0if you 
                                want=
 them as close to the original as possible 
                               =
 is to upload them directly to a 
                                website.
=
                                =A0
                                
      =

                                Original M=
essage ----- 
                                From: 
                      =
          Rj 
                                
                            =
    To: 
                                EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
        =

10, 2009 10:54 AM

                               =
 
                                
                                
       =
                         
                                
Pixelization doe=
sn't clean-up 
                                the data: it replaces it.=A0=
 Imagine taking a 
                                picture of a field of fl=
owers, and beginning to 
                                add levels or pixe=
lization to the picture.=A0 
                                Soon, you woul=
d not be able to tell there were 
                                flowers t=
here at all.=A0 You would see a lot 
                                of col=
ored blocks.

Or in the other 
                                direction, i=
magine you are looking at a 
                                competely rand=
omize bunch of pixes on your 
                                screen: a com=
plete screen of truely random 
                                static snow.=
=A0 Pixelizing this, after a 
                                while, you wo=
uld again start to see colored 
                                blocks.

Wh=
at's happening is that it is 
                                processing an=
 area of the image, taking (for 
                                instance) =
the average value of that entire area, 
                                and=
 replacing all the blocks in that area with 
                              =
  the average.=A0 In video processing, this 
                              =
  would result in a field of multi-colored flowers 
                       =
         being replaced by, for instance, a big 
                          =
      greyish-bluish block, with no resemblance to 
                       =
         flowers.=A0 In the noise example, it maybe 
                      =
          replace all the random pixels with another big 
                 =
               greyish-bluish block.=A0 If you did not know 
              =
                  beforehand what the original picture was, you 
          =
                      couldn't tell whether your pixelized image was 
     =
                           really a field of flowers, a chevy, the sky with=
 
                                clouds, or a random bunch of pixels.

It =

                                works the same with the sound files.=A0 
 =
                               Taking something as complex as speech, and 
=
                                replacing frequencies with their averages, =
loses 
                                the speech the farther you go, until=
 you head 
                                strange fluctuating square waves=
.=A0 Doing 
                                the same to random static will =
eventually 
                                produce the same thing.=A0 And =
random 
                                fluctuating square waves can sound =
a bit like 
                                speech - or at least, you could=
 have fun sharing 
                                with each other what you=
 thing they 'sound 
                                like'.

         =
                       
                                
                  =
              Be a bit careful of formats like 
                           =
     mp3 if you are doing a detailed analysis of the 
                     =
           sounds though.=A0=A0 While some formats 
                       =
         (like wav) can store the audio very close to the 
                =
                way it was recorded, formats like mp3 compress 
           =
                     the file, and in so doing lose some of the sonic 
    =
                            details.=A0 This may not be a big deal in 
    =
                            music, where the audio is fairly clear to begin=
 
                                with.=A0 But with sound sources with a lo=
t of 
                                noise (like evps), this can not only =
obscure any 
                                real sounds, but pixelize non-=
sounds (like white 
                                noise) and make them st=
art to sound like 
                                speech.

So mp3 might be=
 good for sharing 
                                the data, once you've al=
ready formed an opinion 
                                based on an analys=
is of the wav file.=A0 But 
                                mp3 is not good=
 as a medium for analysis.=A0 
                                It can lead =
to many false positives and 
                                misinterpretat=
ions.

ign=3D"top">They are not necessarily the same bytes, but I was 
        pro=
posing a quick check just to see if the files were in the same 
        bal=
lpark.  Look at it the other way: if the number of bytes were 
       =
 DIFFERENT, than you'd know the files HAD changed, and you could stop 
    =
    testing.  But if the number of bytes are the same, it tends to 
  =
      indicate the files are likely the same, but you still need a low leve=
l 
        file comparison to be sure.<br><br>My method is to compare the f=
iles 
        using the CMP command in unix.  There are many programs =
to compare 
        files, but you have to be careful not to use one that d=
oes a 
        line-by-line compare (or a comparison meant for text files),=
 since text 
        files can be different at a low level, but look essent=
ial the same in an 
        editor (because of the way spaces and tabs and =
new lines work between 
        editors and platforms).<br><br>But anyway, =
the way to compare is with a 
        program that can compare binary files=
, not text files.<br><br><br>--- On

                <td valign=3D"top">A=
 file's content, it's integrity, is simply the 
                  bytes (an=
d their bits) in the file.  If the file's 
                  content i=
ntegrity is changed, that is, by definition, changing 
                  th=
e bytes.  If the bytes in there are not changed, then 
               =
   that integrity has not changed.<br><br>It is possible to mess 
         =
         with other things about a file (like its name, its suffix, or 
   =
               its ownership) but this does not effect the contents, and so=
 
                  would not affect that integrity, or the sound of the fi=
le 
                  (assuming you could read it at all after changing the=
 
                  ownership, or the suffix, etc).<br><br>When you do your=
 tests, 
                  if you cannot do a bit level comparison, I would=
 recommend at 
                  least checking the file sizes.  If th=
ey are identical, 
                  there is a very high probability that =
the content has not 
                  changed.<br><br><br><br><br>--- On <=
b>Sun, 5/10/09, April 
                  Abercrombie <i><april@abercromb=
iegh ostresearch. 
                  com></i></b> wrote:<br>

                 <tr>
                          <td valign=3D"top">Yes you =
can tell loss of quality by a 
                            bit-level compar=
ison.  An audio file is just a 
                            file of by=
tes, that is later interpreted by an audio 
                            pla=
yer.  Two files with the exact same 
                            conte=
nts, whether they are audio or image or a 
                            daba=
base or an exe, are indistinguishable from each 
                          =
  other.  That is, if I copied the contents of 
                      =
      one to a new file, and the contents of the other to 
                =
            a new file, and asked you which file each came from, 
         =
                   there would be no way to tell.  Even the audio 
   =
                         player could not tell.  The data is identical=
, 
                            and so the sound (or the picture, etc) would=
 be 
                            identical.<br><br>Yes I did listen to the =
results, 
                            but that is not the best test (they s=
ounded 
                            identical, but that is a subjective opi=
nion).  
                            The real test is compring the con=
tents.  
                            Identical contents means indentic=
al data, means 
                            identical audio.<br><br>It is p=
robably possible to 
                            set up an email compressio=
n scheme that does do 
                            lossy audio compression.=
  My tests show my 
                            setup does not.  =
If you'd like me to help test 
                            your setup, we c=
an do that too. From what I see, 
                            lossy compres=
sion from an attachment would be very 
                            unusual.=
<br><br><br>--- On <b>Sun, 5/10/09, April

crombie <i><april@abercrombiegh ostresearch.
